data.title: Run docker as sudo by default
data.body:
## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: Hosted
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: Ubuntu16 + others

## Issue Description
 
See https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/1937 for details about the scenario 

When running a build step in a container, docker tasks do not work because the user does not have access to the docker socket on the host. 

On the Ubuntu 1604 host, the build agent runs as a user in the docker group so they can run docker without sudo. However, when running in a container it is a different user who is not in the group. 

Running docker commands with sudo by default will allow this scenario to work

data.title: Feature Request: Web Deploy allow for using IIS Virtual Directory
data.body:
## Feature Request

## Environment
- VSTS - (More specifically IIS Web Deploy Task)

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description / Suggested Feature
The IIS Web Manage Task allows for me to create a Virtual Directory, to set it's path and everything from a management point of view. This requires that a 'website' already exists for the virtual directory to be attached to.

From the IIS Web Deploy task, I am unable to specify that I am deploying to a virtual directory or to make use of the Virtual Directory that I created in the previous step of Web Manage. I'm trying to setup this release pipeline to be idempotent so that if and when I change the server I'm running on it'll reconfigure / install the IIS as need be to reduce the need for IT departments interaction.

I do not know if this is already allowed, I could not find documentation on configuring Web Deploy to deploy to a Virtual Directory in a website. So right now it's just deploying to the root directory of the IIS website it's pointed at. (I'd say a combo box that defaults to root and that can be overridden with a text value like the tags box might be a great easy win if this is a easy feasible idea at all?)

data.title: Visual Studio Versions of DAC take precedence over SQL Versions
data.body:
## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

## Environment
- Server - VSTS or TFS on-premises?
    VSTS

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    Hosted
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:
VS2017

## Issue Description

Publish of DACPAC file works on the first attempt
Publish of DACPAC file works on the second attempt
Select columns are then encrypted via a PowerShell scipt to enable Always on Encryption.
Data is added to the tables
Publish of DACPAC files fails with the below error.

This can be replicated with Visual Studio 15.8 locally, this returns the error:
Cannot proceed as Key Vault support is not present in the current application. For Key Vault support during deployment, install DacFramework.msi and run SqlPackage.exe from its install location.

### Error logs

2018-08-29T11:07:41.5950873Z *** Failed to decrypt column 'Password'.
2018-08-29T11:07:41.5959353Z Failed to decrypt a column encryption key. Invalid key store provider name: 'AZURE_KEY_VAULT'. A key store provider name must denote either a system key store provider or a registered custom key store provider. Valid system key store provider names are: 'MSSQL_CERTIFICATE_STORE', 'MSSQL_CNG_STORE', 'MSSQL_CSP_PROVIDER'. Valid (currently registered) custom key store provider names are: . Please verify key store provider information in column master key definitions in the database, and verify all custom key store providers used in your application are registered properly.

I believe that this is happing as the newly updated hosted agent has a newer version of the DAC Framework which is taking precedence over the full version which has been installed separately.  Looking back in my release log history it appears that a week or so ago I was using the agent hosted at C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\140\DAC\bin\SqlPackage.exe rather than at C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\Extensions\Microsoft\SQLDB\DAC\150\SqlPackage.exe

As there are two different versions with different functionality it would be useful if the tasks had the option to select which version of the tool to use (like how the Azure Powershell task works).  Alternatively is there a good way to programmatically locate the correct version of the sqlpackage.exe file so that I can write a script which does this for me?

data.title: VsTestv2: Mark task as SucceededWithIssues if tests had to be re-run
data.body: The option to re-run failed tests in VsTestv2 is nice but I still want to see if a 'green' run had to rerun at least 1 test in order to be 'green'. At the moment I have to look into each release result in order to know that information (because it is still worthwhile to investigate why a test failed sporadically). Marking the task as SucceededWithIssues if all tests passed but at least one test had to be re-run will make the build/release appear as orange, which will help me to know which results I need to look into at some point (i.e. I can defer this task, which I would not do for an actual failure)

data.title: [Service fabric deploy] Diff package should only be created for an upgrade scenario
data.body:
Diff package creation takes dependency on the currently deployed application. In case the application is removed(if user has selected to overwrite application), then diff package becomes invalid.
Hence we should only create diff package in case of application upgrade.

data.title: ServiceFabric Deploy Task upgrade exit states.
data.body:
Service Fabric Deploy task => while upgrading it should exit checking upgrade status when the UpgradeState is either one of the below-mentioned ones

Invalid - Indicates the upgrade state is invalid. All Service Fabric enumerations have the invalid type. The value is zero.
RollingBackCompleted - The upgrade has finished rolling back. The value is 2
RollingForwardCompleted - The upgrade has finished rolling forward. The value is 5
Failed - The upgrade has failed and is unable to execute FailureAction. The value is 6


https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/servicefabric/sfclient-model-upgradestate

data.title: Installing additional go tools
data.body:
## Troubleshooting
This is not a bug report - I'm more interested in how I could solve my problem.
## Environment
- Server: VSTS
    
- Agent: Hosted  

## Issue Description
I'm trying to build a repository containing `golang` code. Now that would not be the problem on VSTS but I have to restore dependencies using [`dep`](https://github.com/golang/dep). This demands the following steps:

1. Fetch the `dep` tool:
```
go get -u github.com/golang/dep/cmd/dep
```
This should compile the dep tool and place it in `$GOPATH/bin`.

2. The I'd have to use this tool to restore dependencies:
```
dep ensure
```
3. The we can build the program:
```
go build main.go -o main
```
Now, step one and three are not a problem and they are covered by the prerelease go tasks. But how could I install the `dep` tool?

data.title: Qualys on WinAgent: Requested registry access is not allowed
data.body:
## Environment
Agent: 2.133.3
OS: Windows 10.0.14393

VSTS agent running inside an Azure VM with Qualys agent

## Issue Description

If a security application (eg. qualys) is installed some registry keys (uses registry as credential storage) are not readable by `NETWORK SERVICE` user and vsts agent failed to run Azure Powershell Script tasks. The tasks are already failing in the setup phase (before running the user task) where the agent wants to list the installed software.

Affected registry keys are under:

- HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall
- HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE

The task fails with a `Requested registry access is not allowed.` exception and prevents any build.

As the registry permissions are a windows feature the agent should be able to deal with locked registry keys and should be able to proceed.

### Error logs
```
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6592868Z ##[section]Starting: PowerShell: xxxxxxx
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6851546Z ==============================================================================
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6851927Z Task         : Azure PowerShell
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6852210Z Description  : Run a PowerShell script within an Azure environment
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6852495Z Version      : 2.0.11
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6852859Z Author       : Microsoft Corporation
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6853181Z Help         : [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613749)
2018-07-26T06:06:48.6853512Z ==============================================================================
2018-07-26T06:06:50.2634580Z Added TLS 1.2 in session.
2018-07-26T06:06:50.7792363Z ##[error]Requested registry access is not allowed.
2018-07-26T06:06:50.8091236Z ##[section]Finishing: PowerShell: xxxxxxxx
```

## "Workarounds"

- Allow NETWORK SERVICE to read these keys (security credentials are readable by all vsts users!)
- Uninstall security software

see also https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-agent/issues/1707

data.title: New task for publish checkstyle (or other static code analysis) results
data.body:
## Environment
- Server - VSTS

## Issue Description

We have the option within Gradle or Maven tasks to execute and report static code analysis (checkstyle, PMD, Findbugs.  This is great, but I can't use gradle or maven with my pipeline.

We also have a task to publish test results, which just looks for test result files matching known formats (Junit, Xunit, etc).  This is great, since I can leverage these formats to get other tools to report results into VSTS.

I would like to have an additional task that publishes static code analysis result files that come from any arbitrary source, so long as they have the correct format, much like we can for unit tests.

When working with Jenkins, we leveraged the Analysis Collector Plugin (https://wiki.jenkins.io/display/JENKINS/Analysis+Collector+Plugin) with checkstyle extension to make this easy.  

Lack of this in VSTS is currently a barrier to my team moving our pipeline over to a VSTS-native solution.

data.title: Release Pipeline view (preview feature) doesn't show the current progress
data.body:
When using ##vso[task.setprogress value=x] in a PowerShell deployment script, the progress won't be shown in the release pipeline view (preview feature) on VSTS.

The current deployment view will show the percentage as a tooltip on the current deployment step (this was fixed with issue #4006). The tooltip on the new release pipeline view doesn't show this information. Visually it would be nicer to have it outside a tooltip so you don't need to hover the mouse over a particular part of the window.

**Steps for reproduction**
- Have a build with an artifact
- Create new empty Release Definition
- Add PowerShell Task and switch to "Inline"
Add following Code to inline input:
```
Write-Host "Hello World!"
for ($i = 0; $i -le 100; $i += 10)
{
  Write-Host ([string]::Format("##vso[task.setprogress value={0};]Deploy {1}", [int] $i, "MySolution"))
  Write-Host ([string]::Format("Task: {1} / Perc: {0}", [int] $i, "MySolution"))
  Start-Sleep -Seconds 1
}
```
- Queue new Release

Tested with a private Agent

data.title: Feature request - ServiceFabricUpdateManifestsV2 support for compressed artifacts
data.body:
If you compress your artifacts when using this task, the task is unable to determine which services have updated and which have not. The result is that the task marks every service as having been upgraded, which results in a full deployment which is slow.

The workaround is to ensure our artifacts are published in an uncompressed format, but this adds minutes to the build time as publishing takes a significantly longer period of time. If this task was able to work with compressed artifacts, we would be able to further optimise our build.

data.title: "Update Service Fabric Manifests" Task does not update DataPackageVersion attributes
data.body:
## Issue Description

When using the "Update Service Fabric Manifests" task to update version numbers in an Application containing a Service that includes a Data package, the task will update the version number of the Data package in ServiceManifest.xml, but not the corresponding references to the Data package in ApplicationManifest.xml.

The most notable example of where this is needed is in [the CertificateRef elements](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-fabric/service-fabric-securing-containers) which can be used to import certificates into containers.

See also Azure/service-fabric-issues#806.

data.title: Override existing files without prompt.
PublishTestResults defaults to GMT time zone for xUnit test results
data.body:
## Environment
TFS 2017 on-premises, using either v1 or v2 (preview) of the PublishTestResults task

## Issue Description

After using the PublishTestResults  task to publish xUnit test results to TFS,  the test run summary shows that the test run completed several hours before its actual completion.  The time delta corresponds to the difference between local time (common to both the test execution environment and the TFS server) and GMT.  The times in the xUnit results file (both `assemblies\timestamp` and `assembly\run-time`) also correspond to local time, but they appear to be interpreted as GMT during processing.

Since the xUnit results file does not contain time zone information, there seems to be little reason to prefer GMT over local time.  While the GMT default may be desirable in some cases, it would be useful to be able to override this in the PublishTestResults task configuration.  Otherwise, users may easily be led to assume that they are examining test results from a different build.  (The current offset behaviour may also lead to problems with workflows that impose limits on test result "staleness".)

data.title: AppCenterTest task overwrites the Run Id build property if used more than once.
data.body:
## Issue Description

AppCenterTest task overwrites the Run Id build property if used more than once. The scenario is Multi-configuration build definitions. 

https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AppCenterTest/appcentertest.ts#L203-L227

The call to patch the build id into the build's properties does not have any unique key when it comes to phases and parallelism, so every time this task is used on a Build, this build property only has the latest to test run that was submitted. Instead some unique key per phase/job name should be used?

It would also be much easier is the task set a local output variable, instead of requiring us to use the REST API just to get the test run id.

data.title: Feature: ability to set a release variable ("##vso[release.setvariable variable=varname;]$value")
data.body:
General availability to set a release variable from within a powershell script path/ inline script would appeal to many.

Overview: I want RM to leverage a dynamic number of test agents for automated testing. The test agents are always contained by a known resource group, but quantity and names may change. For cost saving, the test agent VMs do not need to run outside of the testing that is orchestrated by VSTS RM.

My use case:
1. hosted phase 1: task to get list of vms from a resource group and set the list to a release variable
2. hosted phase 2: configure phase with Parallelism - Multi-configuration and set multipliers to vm list from phase 1. Phase creates "n" number of agents based on parsing the CSV vm string list. Phase passes 1/n vm names to each agent. Agent processes subsequent tasks per each target vm in parallel (like start/stop/configure).

data.title: AppCenterDistribute - Support Absolute File Path
data.body:
## Environment
TFS On-Premises
Version 15.117.26615.0

Private Agents
Windows Server 2012 RT and macOS v10.12.6
Agent Versions: 1.105.6 and 2.117.2


## Issue Description
The [AppCenterDistribute](https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AppCenterDistribute) task uses the description *Relative path from the repo root to the APK or IPA file you want to publish* for the app file input. The underlying logic uses the `vsts-task-lib`'s `findMatch(..)` to try to resolve the path. See https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AppCenterDistribute/utils.ts#L156

This uses globbing logic and will can fail for paths with special characters or absolute paths. When using the task from a release definition in (at least in our on premise version of tfs) the release tasks automatically prepend the working directory to relative paths.

The task should be updated to first check `tl.exists(...)` to determine if it is an absolute path before attempting to find a match for a relative path.

data.title: Anonymous Web Hook for Build Trigger with external git source
data.body:
For external git source, the only way to setup build trigger is pull git source at regular interval. 

External git providers such as gitlab.com and even self hosted git repositories provide simple web hooks. If there is a unique url to trigger build for external git source, it will be helpful. 

Currently there are long workarounds to setup azure function, use vsts API with personal access token to login and submit build, but that is all maintenance overhead.

data.title: Index and Publish Symbols should have an option to automatically include only project outputs that were created in the current build scope
data.body:
If I have a solution with >100 projects where many reference third party assemblies or in-house assemblies built as part of other solutions, its often tedious and time consuming work to setup the build tasks to collect just the symbols for the assemblies that were built as part of this solution and not the other referenced pdb's. 

It would be great if the index and publish symbols task could be a bit smarter and only get the pdb's for assemblies compiled by a vs or msbuild task in the current build (for the debuggable kind - class library, win svc, etc, but not unit test, posh,  wix, etc ).

Perhaps the vs or ms build tasks would be better served to have the index and publish option. I just know I need the symbols stored and easily usable, and that my symbols server is full of stuff it doesnt need due to the overly inclusive search patterns.

data.title: Azure Resource Group Deployment - Missing override template parameters error should be warning.
data.body:
## Environment
- Server - VSTS     

## Issue Description

In our current **VSTS** release pipeline we use the **Azure Resource Group Deployment** step.
(Create Or Update Resource Group)

Every time a new PBI that contains ARM template changes passes we hit the same roadblock.
A developer adds override template parameters  to the VSTS step during feature branch work, and deploys a test release _before merging master._

These new parameters are obviously missing from the current "stable" version of the ARM template (rt/rtp) files. 
Currently the step notifies us about this using an error which stops the release.

**Could you change that error into a warning?**

**Why?**
When we need to hotfix master, the hotfix release won't deploy because the parameters are missing from the old version of the ARM template.  Also consecutive CI merges won't release either.

Currently we resort to creating 'Draft' releases and then copy everything over after merging, but that's an incredible hassle (partly because the person merging into master isn't always the same as the original developer doing the feature branch work.)

data.title: Feature request: Support Azure Sql dacpac deployment task for VSTS agents with SSDT nuget package installed
data.body:
**Feature request:** Support Azure Sql dacpac deployment task for VSTS agents with SSDT nuget package installed.

**Use case:**
We want to use docker windows containers as VSTS agents in our release definitions and want containers to be as light as possible. So we want to install SqlPackage.exe from **Microsoft.data.tools.msbuild** nuget package .

Currently Azure Sql dacpac deployment task works if SqlPackage.exe is installed by methods mentioned at 
[https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/SqlAzureDacpacDeployment#automation-agent](url)  and doesn't support SqlPackage.exe installed via installing **Microsoft.data.tools.msbuild** nuget package .

The task fails with error as mentioned in [https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/5574](url)

data.title: Pattern matching consistency
data.body:
## Goals: 1. For inputs that accept a glob pattern, the helpmarkdown for the input should provide a link for users to understand what syntax is supported.

Ideally this should be a link to the task's help topic (see the Copy Files task). This allows the task's help topic to give specific examples (relevant to that task). And then the task's help topic links over to the generic syntax reference document.

For any tasks without a help topic in place, a low cost alternative is available. Add an FWLINK to the input helpmarkdown that links to the pattern syntax reference: [https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077) 2. All in-the-box tasks should expose a consistent globbing experience. Some tasks are using the old, proprietary pattern matching library. And less severe, some tasks are using an older version of the task lib, before a consistent set of recommended default options was added (vsts-task-lib 2.x). [Task author guidance is here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-task-lib/blob/master/node/docs/findingfiles.md). ## Task changes The following tasks either have an input that does not have a link, or are using the old, proprietary pattern matching library. - [ ] AndroidSigning - files - Needs link - [ ] ANT - testResultsFiles - Needs link - [ ] AzureCloudPowerShellDeployment - csCfg - Needs link - [ ] AzureCloudPowerShellDeployment - csPkg - Needs link - [ ] AzureResourceGroupDeployment - csmFile - Needs link - [ ] AzureRmWebAppDeployment - Package - Needs link - [ ] AzureRmWebAppDeployment - JSONFiles - Needs link - [ ] IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup - Package - Needs link - [ ] IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup - JSONFiles - Needs link - [ ] cURLUploader - files - Needs link - [ ] DeleteFiles - https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/docs/build/steps/utility/delete-files - Needs link - [ ] DotNetCoreCLI - searchPatternPush - Needs link - [ ] Gradle - testResultsFiles - Needs link - [ ] Grunt - testResultsFiles - Needs link - [ ] Gulp - testResultsFiles - Needs link - [ ] Gulp - data.title: [Azure Key Vault] Option to download only secrets or certificates
data.body:
The access policies for Azure Key Vault now differentiate between certificates and secrets. It would be great if we had an option to configure the task only to retrieve either `secrets` or `certificates`.

_In our scenario, we're using the the Key Vault Task to retrieve certificates and use them for a deployment. We aren't using secrets at all. We configured out SPN with get, list permissions on Certificates but the task fails since it tries to get and list all secrets. It would be great if we had an option to restrict downloading of all secrets but continue downloading all certificates._

    2017-08-13T14:50:48.5691700Z ##[error]Get secrets failed. Error: Operation "list" is not allowed by vault policy. Specified Azure endpoint needs to have Get, List secret management permissions on the selected key vault. Set these secret permissions in Azure portal.

data.title: PublishCodeCoverageResults is slow with many files in the generated report
data.body:
related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vsts-tasks/issues/1271

Hi there, we have a project whose coverage report (like the above closed issue) generates over 900 files as its HTML coverage summary output. The PublishCodeCoverageResults task takes about as much time as it takes to generate the coverage report effectively doubling the time to complete our CI tasks. It takes over 2 minutes to publish our code coverage output (which in total is around 4MB).

Is it possible that the task is uploading each file one at a time? Can this be changed to zip the files (which are all text files), then upload the zip, and finally expand on the VSTS side?

- Does `parentid` need to be passed with every request or is it a write once field like `name` or `order`?

- What format should the GUIDs be in?
- What should we be putting in for `type`? The two examples that you show use `build` as the value passed in, should we always pass in `build` or are there other valid values?
